newsitem.title: INDIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - March 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - March 11.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indian business and political stories in leading newspapers prepared for Reuters by Business News and Information Services Pvt Ltd, New Delhi Tel:3324842, 3351006, 3761233 Fax:+91-11-3351006 Internet: biznis@giasbm01.vsnl.net.in
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
TOP STORIES
Indian Express
GOVERNENMENT'S BID TO AVOID VOTE ON GOVERNOR

Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda was learnt to have requested former prime minister Chandra Shekhar's help to sort out the imbroglio in Uttar Pradesh, even before the motion to recall the state governor was taken up for discussion. Gowda, fearing disunity within the ruling coalition on the issue, wants the issue settled amicably through negotiations with the opposition.
The Economic Times
HPCL, TOTAL SETTING UP 18 BLN RUPEE LNG PLANT

The Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (HPCL) and Total of France would set up an 18 billion rupee liquid natural gas (LNG) terminal project in southern India, and a 500 megawatt gas based power plant near the terminal. Both HPCL and Total would hold 26 percent each in the joint venture. The rest would be offered to other prospective partners and the public. The debt equity ratio was expected to be around 2:1. The total equity of the project would be six billion rupees.
TATA RAYTHEON VENTURE IN DOUBT

Problems for the Tata Raytheon Bangalore airport project appear to be mounting as the government rejected the proposal to shut the Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL) airport. Closure of the HAL airport, which was agreed upon, was viewed as a crucial step towards making the proposed Tata consortium airport a profitable one since it guaranteed a complete load of traffic in and out of Bangalore to the new airport. With this rejection, the earlier commitment made to transfer all international and domestic flights to the new airport was also killed.
PANEL FOR SCRAPPING FIVE GOVERNMENT PROJECTS

As part of the government's tight expenditure management strategy, an expert panel suggested shelving of five government owned projects, including the 22 billion rupee Koel Karo hydel power project in Bihar. The four remaining projects belong to the railways.
BOURSE CRASHES ANOTHER 107 POINTS

Pivotals in most of the bourses registered their first major single day fall since the budget. The Bombay bourse index tumbled 107 points to close at 3,768.74. Pivotals were marked down further in late evening kerb deals.
COAL, RAILWAY MINISTRIES TOLD TO SHARE PROJECT RISKS

The railways and coal ministries will share the risk premium in the Hinduja's Vishakapatnam power plant. This was decided by a cabinet sub-committee which met to thrash out differences between various arms of the government over the power purchase agreement for the project. This was the first instance of union ministries being asked to share the risk burden for a project being set up in the private sector.
Financial Express
THREE BANKS CUT DEPOSIT RATES

Three state-owned banks slashed their short-term deposit rates by one to two percentage points. The move was aimed at discouraging major interbank call lenders from parking their funds in short-term bank deposits. Private and foreign-owned banks, on their part, were turning down such depositors. The depositors, mainly insurance companies and financial institutions, were seeking better yields through the short-term deposit route, because of the low interbank call rates.
PRUDENTIAL CORP SCOUTS FOR PARTNERS IN INDIA

Prudential Corporation is scouting for a domestic partner to enter the pension and life insurance business in India. The company has sought clearances from the government to open an office. The corporation is likely to announce the name of its Indian joint venture partner within six months.
TWO MEGA POWER PROJECTS FOR TAMIL NADU

The Tamil Nadu government is drawing up a plan for two thermal power plants of between 1,500 and 2,000 megawatt each. The plants have been conceived as a wholly private sector venture and the state power utility is working out the modalities before calling for international tenders. The cost of setting up the two plants would be 120 billion to 160 billion rupees.
Business Standard
170 BLN RUPEE MOPUP VIA SECURITIES IN FEBRUARY

The Reserve Bank of India mopped up large sums of both short-term and long-term funds from the system in February. The mop-up of short-term liquidity in the system, through sale and repurchase of securities (repos), led to a withdrawal of 170 billion rupees in February. The second fortnight of the month also witnessed a mop-up of long-term funds aggregating 17 billion rupees through open market operations.
BRITISH GAS PLANS TO INVEST IN POWER, LNG

British Gas International plans to invest more than $1.5 billion in power generation projects besides distribution and sale of liquefied natural gas (LNG). It has bid for setting up a dual fuel fired power plant and has been qualified along with 12 other bidders. It was also conducting a feasibility study for importing and distributing LNG. The British major already has a joint venture with the Gas Authority of India.
The Observer
MORE TAX RELIEF FOR COMPANY RECAST IN THE OFFING

One more package of relief in income tax was expected in the near future, particularly provisions related to sale and purchase of immovable properties and restructuring of companies. The expert group, appointed to suggest reforms in the existing tax rate structure, recommended scrapping of the sections concerned with the powers vested with the income tax authority over sale and purchase of immovable properties.
BRITISH TELECOM PLANS STAKE IN BHARTI'S TELECOM VENTURE

British Telecom (BT), which recently acquired 22.5 percent equity in Bharti Cellular, was in talks with the Mittals to pick up an equity stake in the latter's basic telecommunication venture for Madhya Pradesh. Bharati Televenture of the Mittal group, which holds the licence for operating basic services in Madhya Pradesh, has an open slot of 19 percent equity. BT is trying to buy into this open slot and negotiations are at an advanced stage.
